user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__epoll:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__epoll (const char *param_name)
{
  if (tool_params.poll)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-p' or '--poll'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.select)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-s' or '--select'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.epoll = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Rule 21.17 concerns use of functions from <string.h>. The fragment does not call any <string.h> function, so Rule 21.17 is not violated. Note: the code does read param_name[1], which may be out-of-bounds if param_name points to a string shorter than 2 characters (e.g. "" or a single-character string) — that would be undefined behavior and could violate other MISRA rules, but it is not a violation of Rule 21.17.
